App description:
Winner of over 50 awards, including Giant Bomb and Eurogamer 2018 Game of the Year!

Tetris Effect is Tetris like you've never seen it, or heard it, or felt it beforea breathtakingly gorgeous reinvention of one of the most popular puzzle games of all time, from the people who brought you the award-winning Rez Infinite and legendary puzzle game Lumines.

Music, backgrounds, sounds, special effectseverything, down to the Tetriminos themselves, pulse, dance, shimmer, and explode in perfect sync with how you're playing, making any of the game's 30+ stages and 10+ modes something you'll want to experience over and over again.

All-new Zone mechanic: Players can stop time (and Tetriminos falling) by entering the Zone and either get out of a sticky situation that could otherwise lead to Game Over, or rack up extra Line Clears for bonus scoring rewards.

Tetris  &  1985~2020 Tetris Holding.

IamStorm23 days ago
Love this game! Get it!

I never ever thought Id buy Tetris for VR. Ive never been a big fan of the game or played it much growing up.

I took a chance after reading some reviews and bought this game, and I am blown away! I love the music, the visuals, and everything about it. Its incredibly fun to play and the music is really good! I dont like every song, but theres like 25 to choose from, and different difficulty settings. Im actually getting pretty good at the game after a week of playing.

If youre on the fence, like the music (Hydelic on Spotify) and want to have a great game experience... Try this game out! Worth the price.

PilotFawn10 days ago
So much more than Tetris

My hubby has had a vive and a quest for some time & having tried it I suffer awful vertigo & was limited to just one game.

Loved Tetris years ago but when he downloaded Tetris effect I fell in love with it. Its more than just a Tetris game, it is a beautiful experience.

The light shows and music is awesome to the point I often play the soundtrack outside VR but it also spurred me to buy my very own Quest because finally I have a game for me!

I love journey mode but great to just dip in for the effects mode & take part in the weekly ritual.

This is way more than Tetris & the perfect way to wind down after a tough day. Seriously give it a try!

Tetris..just not as we know it

I was a bit sceptical before buying this as I thought its just Tetris right? But I was wrong.

Citadel17May 14 at 10:48 PM
This is, without a doubt, a masterpiece.

Tetris games aren't meant to be considered high art.

Tetris games aren't meant to make you lose your sense of place.

Tetris games aren't meant to make you feel at one with humanity and the universe.

And Tetris games especially aren't meant to make you tear up.

But here's Tetris Effect, a Tetris game that fits all of these categories.

This is a work of art, and I encourage anybody to get it. You know how to play it. It's Tetris. But it's Tetris that will make you lost in the gameplay and cause you to feel at peace within the world. Absolute 10/10, please experience this.

AzulRoyalJul 3 at 6:59 AM
Tetris. AMPLIFIED.

To call this just simple Tetris is a frickin' understatement. Oh it's definitely still Tetris, but with all the intricate worlds literally coming to life around you as you play it's very much a mega glorified version of it. The visuals are amazingly pretty and the music is riveting. Literally every move you make, the turning of your blocks and crashing them down, builds upon the music and sound effects literally becomes the music. You essentially use your moves to get the music going. It's very easy to get swept away in it all. It's therapeutic, hypnotic, just EPIC. Very, VERY pleased with this purchase.

Note: There's lots of light effects in this game, so it may not be suitable for certain folks out there.

RickK75May 14 at 3:01 PM
A nice port but don't expect the PC/PSVR

A fairly good port of the PSVR/PC classic...

Pros:
PSVR/PC VR gameplay intact.
Music is a real showcase for how good the Quest in-built audio can be.
Some effort has been made to preserve the visual effects that underpin this title.

Cons:
Reduced effects. Inevitably the Quest can't throw as many particles around.
Some objects on levels which looked sharp and rendered from many tiny dots on the PC instead look like meshes with low res, blurry "dot textures" on the Quest.
I don't think every drop of performance was painstakingly squeezed out of the Quest like it was with Superhot or Space Pirate Trainer.

Verdict:
For a title that is very much about it's visual effects and music, the music survives and surprisingly sounds stunning on the Quest but the visual effects are inevitably turned down from 11 to 7 vs PS4/PC.
The visual fidelity retained is just enough to warrant the title Tetris Effect on Quest without the need for an "Unplugged" subtitle. Any more compromise and it would be TE:Light.

If you've never played the original on PC/PSVR it's an absolute must as you won't notice any of the above compromise.

And, I'd buy it anyway as it's a brave effort at a portable version of the classic!

Believe the hype...

When this came out on other VR platforms a year or so ago, I couldnt understand why there was any need to play Tetris in VR, or why it should be so expensive for a 35 year game which you can effectively play for free on your phone. When it came out on Quest and the 5 star reviews kept rolling in I decided to bite the bullet and see what all the fuss was about.

Now I get it! Firstly, it just works in VR - even back when I played on by gameboy years ago, you only really played well when you got into a sort of flow state where you immersed into the game, playing VR enhances your ability to do that as you are entirely encompassed by the experience.

Next the quality and scale of the different levels, you can totally see how much effort and though has gone into the game, and there for how the cost is justified. From amazing backgrounds that develop as you work through the level to beautiful sound tracks that somehow are able to incorporate your tile movements in harmony with the music, it all feels to polished and immersive.

One piece of advise I would give, Tetris purists may prefer using the A and B buttons to rotate the pieces, but I found it much more intuitive once I swapped out the buttons (which Im pleased to say are completely configurable) so that the left and right triggers turned the pieces anti-clockwise and clockwise respectively. Down to individual preference but it helped me a lot.

As other reviews have said, it needs to be played to fully appreciate it, also, make sure you stick at it, if like me you will probably be terrible at first till you get back into the mechanics of it all again, dont be afraid to swap out pieces regularly, and happy gaming!

thechrisstreet10 days ago
Beautiful. Elegant. Refined. Yet...

I'd spent numerous days during lockdown debating on whether or not to buy an Oculus Quest. I kept weighing up the pros and cons, wanting to justify its purchase.

Then, Tetris Effect was announced - a game I had already experienced and loved, for the Playstation 4. Suddenly I found myself buying the Quest and downloading the game.

Comparisons to the PS4 version are inevitable. The Quest is vastly underpowered compared to home consoles, and I was expecting a massive drop in visual fidelity. After all, I had read numerous reviews beforehand stating that there were fewer special effects, but it was still worth a purchase.

Let me just say right now, I do like Tetris Effect a lot. But I don't love it like I do on PS4. That sense of... immersion... isn't quite there for me, even with headphones. I never felt like I was "in the zone" as I was on PS4 and I kept on thinking I'd rather be playing that instead.

And yet, I keep coming back for more. It's a beautiful game, fantastically put together, held back by lengthy loading times at the start of the game, and in-between cleared areas.

The game controls are easy to pick up, but perhaps a little twitchy - inevitably the downside of using an analogue stick. Too many times I accidentally placed a block by pressing down when I meant to move it left or right. But then I started to get used to it, with only the occasional error on my part.

There are many, many stages. Perhaps, my biggest gripe of all (and this applies to the PS4 version) is that there's no way to have a zen-like experience by practicing ALL the stages in Practice mode... you can only play about half of them, which is a shame. Perhaps this will be addressed in an update.

Overall, do I recommend Tetris Effect? Wholeheartedly... Yes. You'll love it even more if you've never played the PS4 version as you won't have anything to compare it to. It's a very good game. But not a brilliant game.

evandaganMay 18 at 8:02 PM
Why would I need Tetris in VR?

So here's what this is: it's Tetris, with a variety of animated 3D backgrounds.

That's pretty much it, but the backgrounds are beautiful works of art, and the music is fantastic, ranging from ambient electronic to jazz and mixed with more traditional "world music" styles. The music and animated backgrounds are not just simple loops, but evolve and change as you play, apparently taking cues from your actions and progress in the game. This adds up to a whole lot more than the sum of its parts, and really is a great experience. It's almost a rhythm game: you'll find yourself moving pieces in time with the music and getting into the flow.

It can be relaxing/meditative on slower levels, but the faster levels get pretty hectic, but there after time of settings and different modes so you can pick and choose based on your current mood.

So yeah, it's just Tetris, but the VR environments and music really do add something new and it's much more than the sum of its parts.

Docked one star for the price - this would be an easier buy at $15 or $20.

Worst port of an otherwise great game

I was astonished when I saw that Tetris Effect finally came to the Quest and I was curious, since I hadn't gotten the game on any platform yet. I'm a huge fan of the Tetris franchise and I'm starting to become considerably good at the game. So this was a must buy for me.

The good stuff
This game is full of content, especially for seasoned players. The different Effect Modes sure could teach me a few more skills. Coming from Puyo Puyo Tetris I enjoyed its non-compatitive equivalent of Big Bang mode (a mode in which you need to clear your entire field with a given set of tetrominos).

The not so good stuff
Let's face it. The visuals could be better. The particle effects look washed out and even though they are still kind of nice to look at, I imagine the PSVR and PCVR versions are far superior in this department.
What's more important (to me) is that the game tends to lag, sometimes for no apparent reason. As a player striving for highscores and SS ranks I feel like unnecessarily hindered by the occasional lag to the point where I get uncomfortable with playing the game (not in a nausea-induced way, though).Sadly, I couldn't find an option to turn down effects in order to make the game run smoothly all the time.

I really would love to incorporate Tetris Effect into my Tetris Training routine, but as it stands I rather feel ripped off 30 for an inferior port and I don't want to spend money twice in order to get the real deal. So, please, dear developers, I ask you to patch the game so that it becomes the best it could be.

AquareonMay 19 at 12:19 AM
Why is this game rated so highly?

I had to sit through a sixty second loading meter the first time. For Tetris. Let that sink in for a moment. Tetris, a thirty six year old game that originally ran on cold war era microcomputers, now runs on the Unreal engine and takes sixty seconds to load initially, then fifteen seconds every time after that. FOR TETRIS. Why? It's not loading from a disc. This isn't the 5th console gen. This isn't Lumines on PSP. It's loading from fast, solid state memory. How can TETRIS have a loading meter? AND I HAVE TO CLICK THROUGH FOUR SCREENS OF LOGOS BEFORE I EVEN GET TO THE MENU.

I digress. The next sin is that it's thirty dollars. I wanted to put some choice words in here but I'm trying not to give any excuses to take the review down. Thirty dollars for Tetris? Why? Because there's distracting visual fluff littering your peripheral vision, while you play a game about falling blocks? Yes, I bought it, because Quest is starved for content and I like Tetris. When it's cheap, starts instantly and controls properly. Which brings me to complaint number three.

There appears to be no insta-drop button. Maybe I'm a big dummy and somehow overlooked it? Maybe it's a button combo for some reason? I shouldn't have to sit here like a dink holding down on the analogue stick to drop pieces if I know where I want them to go and have them vertically aligned within a second of their appearance at the top of the playfield.

Who is rating this garbage five stars? Were you dropped on your head? Do you clap and giggle at any flashing colored lights brought within your field of view? Does generic mall music enhance a falling blocks game THAT MUCH for you? I feel as if you'd get just as much joy from jangly keys and I'd do that for free. One star.

Grod2001May 18 at 1:12 AM
A masterpiece of Gameplay, Sight & Sound

People generally tend to dismiss this game, seeing it as another version of Tetris. And from the trailers it's hard to showcase exactly how VR could make this different, but when the entire scenery envelops your vision and you're focused on the gameplay, the vibration on your controllers syncing to every movement you do, and the beat of the song thumping and gradually speeding up to match the Rhythm and flow of the game, you find yourself naturally getting better at the at the game making split-second decisions without a thought just because of how in the zone you are.
Calling this just another version of tetris is a disservice to everything these developers worked hard to do. they created a spiritual journey in this game, while that might sound silly it's the plain truth. I've been driven to Tears by this game in it's previous release, and it's done so again in this version. If there ever was a game that can embody Euphoria, this is it.
The price tag might seem steep, but after you find yourself draining the quest is battery in a single session, you won't doubt that it's worth its price twice over.
Any visual downgrade from its previous versions are hardly noticeable while playing, the only major problem I would find with this is that the Oculus touch thumbsticks are not really ideal for the Tetris gameplay, they could be a bit sensitive and I found myself accidentally hard dropping every once in awhile. Tetris is more suited for a d-pad, but you can get used to it or use a third-party gamepad. And trust me when I say you'll have plenty to do in this game, so don't worry about it lacking content.

mcpishMay 16 at 1:56 AM
Fantastic

I'm really happy with this. I was on the fence about it but decided to give it a go. It's the kind of spaced-out/LSD-trip vibe I'd been hoping to find on Quest. It helps if you're into minimal electronic music (I am) and the associated imagery/culture of that whole scene. If so, you'll get what this game is trying to do (and succeeds) by being the sort of trance-inducing/hallucinogenic experience. Every time you move a piece around or rotate it you're essentially composing a layer of the background music that's unique each time. It's pretty amazing that it always sounds good (always in key), and that's a big part of the appeal. There's actually more to the new mechanics as it's now possible to score even more than a Tetris at a time (Octris, and even higher). Using the new mechanic adds a new layer of strategy to classic Tetris. Highly Recommended
